occurrences.line_text: Into his hart, and had so sternely wroke
Of her owne knight, had giuen him his owne due hire.
In which he had good right gaynst all, that it gainesayd.
Which had himselfe so stoutly well acquit;
And when he long had him beholding stood,
All which when well Sir Calidore had heard,
I had, you to reward with greater dignitie.
Thus when they long had treated to and fro,
Who ere he thence had traueild many a mile,
This knight, whom Tristram slew, had wounded sore
When Calidore this ruefull storie had
Which had this outrage wrought with wicked hand.
By many signes, which she described had,
And powring balme, which he had long puruayd,
Vnto the Castle where they had decreed.
That in his youth had beene of mickle might,
But now weake age had dimd his candle light.
To cheare his guests, whom he had stayd that night,
How great a hazard she at earst had made
To which she for his sake had weetingly
To leaue, till to her fathers house he had her brought.
That she her selfe had to the iourney dight,
Of a discourteous Knight, who her had reft,
As he had vow'd, some small continuaunce
His warlike armes he had from him vndight:
And troubled had their quiet loues delight.
And of aduentures, which had in his measure
Which he endured had through daungerous debate.
Or had no courage, or else had no gall.
Or had no courage, or else had no gall.
But the rude Porter that no manners had,
Yet had no meanes to comfort, nor procure her glee.
Had him abusde, and shamed yesterday;
Of the lewd words and deedes, which he had done:
Had not a wondrous chaunce his reskue wrought,
Yet armes or weapon had he none to fight,
And had he not in his extreamest need,
He had him ouertaken in his flight.
Had left that couple, nere their vtmost cast.
For other language had he none nor speach,
Which had them freed from that deadly feare,
So as ere long he had that knightes wound
Least that the beasts sharpe teeth had any wound
And when he had deuized of her case,
That he his loue so lucklesse now had lost,
Who when as now long time he lacked had
Had left behind, he gan eftsoones prepare,
Sir Calepine himselfe away had hidden it.
After that Timias had againe recured
The hardy boy, as they deuised had,
Where I had surely long ere this bene dead,
Had not this wylde man in that wofull stead
Which Turpine had vnto her shewed late,
For well it seem'd, that whilome he had beene
That he had bene a man of mickle name,
Had giuen them, whose griefe through suffraunce sore increast.
Which had in many fortunes tossed beene,
And in the mindes of men had great insight;
For whylome he had bene a doughty Knight,
He found that they had festred priuily,
Which at the first before it had infected,
So lewdly had abusde, as ye did lately heare.
Which faire Serene to him deliuered had,
With which he had those two so ill bestad:
Receiued had, and prayd to pitty his ill plight.
Who when he once his dreadfull strokes had tasted,
But when the Prince had once him plainely eyde,
As one that had no life him left through former feare.
He had behynd him left that saluage wight,
With slaughtred bodies, which his hand had slaine,
After he gotten had with busie paine
As if he long had to his heasts bene trayned.
He had not left one limbe of him vnrent:
On him, that had so shamefully him shent:
Had doen to him, and his deare Ladie shent:
Which neuer yet they had approu'd in fight;
And ere that litle while they ridden had,
That for his sake his deare life had forgone;
He there in shade himselfe had layd to rest,
Like as that other knight to him had sayd:
Had vow'd vnto the victor, him to trace
Had for his food late gathered from the tree,
Did boast her beautie had such soueraine might,
Till she had sau'd so many loues, as she did lose.
So now she had bene wandring two whole yeares
Yet had she not in all these two yeares space,
She had destroyed two and twenty more.
Else had he surely there bene slaine, or fowlyshent.
Ne powre had to withstand, ne hope of any ayd.
He in his necke had set his foote with fell disdaine.
To loue my selfe I learned had in schoole.
As if he neuer had receiued fall;
And sure I weene, had not the Ladies cry
Tho when as all her plaints she had displayd,
His brode black wings had through the heauens wyde
Long had he sought her, and through many a soyle
Had traueld still on foot in heauie armes,
If such a beast they saw, which he had thether brought.
Yclad in home-made greene that her owne hands had dyde.
Ne any will had thence to moue away,
But after he had fed, yet did he stay,
As his owne chyld; for other he had none,
After her flocke she in their fold had tyde,
Tho when they had their hunger slaked well,
After I had ten yeares my selfe excluded
And wish the heauens so much had graced mee,
But she that neuer had acquainted beene
Ne euer had such knightly seruice seene,
Had euer learn'd to loue the lowly things,
That who had seene him then, would haue bethought
Long time had lou'd, and hop'd her loue to gaine,
This newcome shepheard had his market mard.
And had he not vpon him fallen light,
His dearest ioynt he sure had broken quight.
From chacing him, till he had it attchieued?
For who had tasted once (as oft did he)
Whose like before his eye had neuer seene,
When thus that shepherd ended had his speach,
That thence, he had no will away to fare,
Had left, now gan afresh to rancle sore,
Dinting his brest, had bred his restlesse paine,
He had no weapon, but his shepheards hooke,
A thousand times him thankt, that had her death preuented.
They spoyld old Melibee of all he had,
It so befell (as Fortune had ordayned)
And had the chiefe commaund of all the rest,
Of all the other pray, which they had got,
Whom they before in diuerse spoyles had caught:
With which none had to doe, ne ought partake,
Had riuen bene, and all her hart strings brast,
Tho when the shepheard breathed had awhile,
First all the captiues, which they here had hent,
When Calidore these ruefull newes had raught,
When she was slaine, or had bene to her succour nere.
But after griefe awhile had had his course,
But after griefe awhile had had his course,
Had vnderneath, him armed priuily.
The selfe same flocks, the which those theeues had reft
But he, that in his mind had closely made
Had from their maisters fled, & now sought hyre elswhere.
Were dead, right so as Coridon had taught:
But chiefly Calidore, whom griefe had most possest.
Had neuer ioyance felt, nor chearefull thought,
And life to feele, that long for death had sought;
Till he had strowd with bodies all the way;
Whereof she long had lackt the wishfull sight,
That long had lyen dead, and made againe aliue.
Which they from many long had robd and rent,
Had reft from Meliboe, and from his make,
Sir Calidore when thus he now had raught
And had endured many a dreadfull stoure
Long since had fought in field. Als Claribell
Of his first quest, which he had long forlore;
The which the Faery Queene had long afore
Bequeath'd to him, forslacked had so sore;
That litle Infant had, which forth she kest,
She in the open fields had loosely layd
To tell her, how the heauens had her graste,
Through all estates he found that he had past,
In which he many massacres had left,
Who now no place besides vnsought had left,
Into their cloysters now he broken had,
After that he had labourd long in vaine,
As if he learned had obedience long,
With his vile tongue, which many had defamed,
To mortall men, then he had done before;
Dead long ygoe I wote thou haddest bin,
Then that thou hadst repented it too late?
It was complaind, that thou hadst done great tort
The diuelish hag by chaunges of my cheare
A loathly, wrinckled hag, ill fauoured, old,
And him behind, a wicked Hag did stalke,
Approching, first the Hag did thrust away,
And eke the Hag with many a bitter threat,
And that same Hag, his aged mother, hight
But that lame Hag, still as abroad he strew
That other Hag did farre away espy
Where sitting on the flore the Hag she found,
And that vile Hag, all were her whole delight
Whom such whenas the wicked Hag did vew,
Of that vile hag, or her vnciuile sonne:
But that accursed Hag, her hostesse late,
Such was that hag, which with Duessa roade,
Vile hag (sayd Scudamour) why dost thou lye?
Made in their friendship, as that Hag him teaches:
Together with this Hag beside her set,
But he shall haue the Hag that is ybet,
For such an Hag, that seemed worse then nought,
Whether shall haue the Hag, or hold the Lady still.
That stryfull hag with gealous discontent
And how that Hag his loue abused had
And after her the Hag, there with her mewed,
Such was that Hag, vnmeet to host such guests,
Yet found no fault, but that the Hag did scold
That shamefull Hag, the slaunder of her sexe,
He brought forth that old hag of hellish hew,
A wicked hag, and Enuy selfe excelling
As hagard hauke presuming to contend
Infernall Hags, Centaurs, feendes, Hippodames,
There follow'd fast at hand two wicked Hags,
Which when those wicked Hags from farre did spy,
When as two old ill fauour'd Hags he met,
Such were these Hags, and so vnhandsome drest:
And euermore those hags them selues did paine,
And arrowes haild so thicke, that they could not abide.
All haile, Sir knight, and well may thee befall,
And pacing fairely forth, did bid all haile,
At length breakes downe in raine, and haile, and sleet,
Haile good Sir Sergis, truest Knight aliue,
When Calidore thus first; Haile noblest Knight
And heaped strokes did round about him haile
That on his shield did rattle like to haile
Haile iolly shepheard, which thy ioyous dayes
That I may wreake on them their hainous hatefull deed.
And breathes out wrath and hainous crueltie;
That am the author of this hainous deed,
Sore trouble of an hainous enimy;
He cast to punish for his hainous fault;
Betrothed me vnto the onely haire
Astond he stood, and vp his haire did houe,
Some frounce their curled haire in courtly guise,
Vpon a bearded Goat, whose rugged haire,
Came dauncing forth, shaking his deawie haire:
His haire, and hastie tongue, that did offend:
With garments rent, and haire discheueled,
As ghastly bug their haire on end does reare:
Drew by the haire along vpon the ground,
That in his crowne he counted her no haire,
As Florimells faire haire: and in the stead
With vpstart haire, and staring eyes dismay,
And her bright browes were deckt with borrowed haire:
All ouergrowne with haire, that could awhape
For all his haire was like a garment seene;
All ouergrowen with rude and rugged haire;
And rent his haire and scratcht his face for paine.
As with a robe, with her owne siluer haire,
Did tricle downe her haire, like to the hore
All goodly damzels, deckt with long greene haire,
She to them runnes in hast, and her haire rends,
As yet not laced, nor her golden haire
A bounch of haires discolourd diuersly:
A bunch of haires discolourd diuersly,
His reuerend haires and holy grauitie
Of ripest yeares, and haires all hoarie gray,
In her rude haires sweet flowres themselues did lap,
By such, as claymd themselues Brutes rightfull haires,
Then taking thrise three haires from off her head,
And all his hairy brest with gory bloud was fild.
See how they doe the Lady hale and draw.
Gan him to hale, and teare, and scratch, and bite;
Th'old woman wox half blanck, those words to heare;
Through vengeful wrath & sdeignfull pride half mad:
Aie me, how could her loue make half amends therefore.
Halfe like a serpent horribly displaide,
But th'other halfe did womans shape retaine,
Halfe furious vnto his foe he came,
Halfe angry asked him, for what he came.
And as halfe blushing offred him to kis,
And halfe enraged at her shamelesse guise,
Halfe mad through malice, and reuenging will,
And halfe ashamed, wondred at the sight:
With loftie eyes, halfe loth to looke so low,
The Marriner yet halfe amazed stares
The mightie trunck halfe rent, with ragged rift
Fled fast away, halfe dead with dying feare:
The mossy braunches of an Oke halfe ded.
Halfe flying, and halfe footing in his hast,
Halfe flying, and halfe footing in his hast,
Halfe dead through feare, her litle babe reuyld,
How may it be, (said then the knight halfe wroth,)
Of death and labour lay, halfe dead, halfe quicke,
Of death and labour lay, halfe dead, halfe quicke,
But he halfe discontent, mote nathelesse
Does scorch not halfe so sore, nor damned ghoste
Faire Sir, (said she halfe in disdainefull wise,)
And therein sate an old old man, halfe blind,
Of hideous Giants, and halfe beastly men,
The Prince him selfe halfe seemeth to offend,
So halfe vnwilling from their bookes them brought,
That halfe the steele behind his back did rest;
Halfe in a maze with horror hideous,
And halfe in rage, to be deluded thus,
And did like an halfe Theatre fulfill:
But th'vpper halfe their hew retained still,
Wherewith her mother Art, as halfe in scorne
Doth light the lower world, were halfe yspent,
The loathed leachour. But the Dame halfe ded
Halfe armd and halfe vnarmd, with them attons:
Halfe armd and halfe vnarmd, with them attons:
Which suddein fit, and halfe extatick stoure
Halfe of thy dayes doest lead in horrour hideous.
He vp arose, as halfe in great disdaine,
And woxe halfe wroth against her damzels slacke,
To whom halfe weeping, she thus answered,
Not halfe so fast the wicked Myrrha fled
Nor halfe so fast to saue her maidenhed,
Whilome begot, being but halfe twin of that berth.
As if the word so spoken, were halfe donne,
The old man could not fly, but fell to ground halfe ded.
He fell halfe dead; next stroke him should haue slaine,
Twixt dolour and despight halfe desperate,
That Britomart halfe enuying their b[l]esse,
Whose scoffed words he taking halfe in scorne,
The other halfe behind yet sticking fast,
Then he halfe vanquisht, then the other seemed,
And fresh assayld his foe; who halfe affeard
But Triamond halfe wroth to see him staid,
And snatching from her hand halfe angrily
The Prince halfe rapt, began on her to dote:
To whom I cald aloud, halfe angry therewithall.
Yet were they brethren both of halfe the blood,
By her I entring halfe dismayed was,
But for he was halfe mortall, being bred
And eke their dame halfe dead did hide her self for feare.
Of which th'one halfe vpon himselfe did set,
And but halfe seene his vgly visnomie,
Ere long their Queene her selfe, halfe like a man
Halfe of her shield he shared quite away,
That halfe her side it selfe did naked show,
Of that sad stroke, that halfe enrag'd she grew,
With that she turn'd her head, as halfe abashed,
As one adaw'd, and halfe confused stood;
He slaughtred had, and ere they were halfe ded,
And with vnwonted terror halfe affray,
That made him stagger, and stand halfe agast
To whom Sir Burbon, blushing halfe for shame,
Her halfe dismayd they found in doubtfull plight,
With Artegall, returning yet halfe sad
He woxe halfe mad, and in that rage gan roue
But where then is (quoth he halfe wrothfully)
And where is eke your friend, which halfe it ought?
He lost himselfe, and like one halfe entraunced grew.
Which gaue him hope, and did him halfe perswade,
And halfe enraged at that ruefull sight;
Vnto her mistresse, being halfe dismayd,
Deuouring, euen that halfe-gnawen snake,
That he Malbeccoes halfen eye did wyle,
His halfen eye he wiled wondrous well,
And heauenly lampes were halfendeale ybrent:
Him sternely grypt, and haling to and fro,
Haling her palfrey by the hempen raines.
Scourging and haling him more vehement;
Thence to the hall, which was on euery side
The heapes of people thronging in the hall,
Feasting and courting both in bowre and hall;
And forth he comes into the commune hall,
Which wast begot in Dï¿½mogorgons hall,
Nor voice was heard, nor wight was seene in bowre or hall.
And gladly did them guide, till to the Hall they came.
All in the open hall amazed stood,
And brought them vp into her castle hall;
Thence she them brought into a stately Hall,
And through the Hall there walked to and fro
To be the same which in her fathers hall
And dayly feasting both in bowre and hall,
he comes to Proteus hall,
All these together marched toward Proteus hall.
Came to the open hall, to listen whose
Fayre Florimell, into the common hall,
Throughout the hall, for that same warlike horse.
And drawing him out of the open hall,
She heard a wondrous noise below the hall.
Went vp the hall, that was a large wyde roome,
The marshall of the hall to them did come;
And ran into the Hall, where he did weene
And well beseemeth that in Princes hall
Thence passing forth, into the hall he came,
Ne stayd, till that he came into the hall:
Into his Lords forbidden hall to passe.
He which doth summon louers to Loues iudgement hall.
And this your cabin both my bowre and hall.
Great Neptune, I auow to hallow vnto thee.
Whooping, and hallowing on euery part,
He chose an halter from among the rest,
And round about his necke an halter tight,
That forst him th'halter from his hand to loose,
Below her ham her weed were somewhat traine,
Vp to her ham, but when she list, it raught
The wooddy Nymphes, faire Hamadryades
So huge his hammer and so fierce his heat,
And heaped blowes like yron hammers great:
When heauie hammers on the wedge are swaid;
Of many yron hammers beating ranke,
With huge great hammers, that did neuer rest
So likewise did the hammers which they bore,
The hammers sound his senses did molest;
Enforst to seeke some couert nigh at hand,
Who nought aghast, his mightie hand enhaunst:
That hand or foot to stirre he stroue in vaine:
And knitting all his force got one hand free,
He stayde his hand, and gan himselfe aduise
With sword in hand, and with the old man went;
His foe was nigh at hand. He prickt with pride
Astonied with the stroke of their owne hand,
Whose forged beauty he did take in hand,
The false witch did my wrathfull hand with-hold;
In hand of leachour vylde.
To weet, if dwelling place were nigh at hand;
His bleeding hart is in the vengers hand,
Himselfe too nigh at hand, but turned wyde
Till Vna cride, O hold that heauie hand,
His hastie hand he doth amazed hold,
Left in the hand of that same Paynim bold,
As euer wielded speare in warlike hand,
Through highest heauen with weaker hand to rayne;
And in her hand she held a mirrhour bright,
And in his hand his Portesse still he bare,
And in his hand did beare a bouzing can,
And in his hand a burning hart he bare,
A vile disease, and eke in foote and hand
And in his hand a burning brond he hath,
And on his dagger still his hand he held,
Rode Sathan, with a smarting whip in hand,
That brothers hand shall dearely well requight
Therewith his heauie hand he high gan reare,
His cunning hand gan to his wounds to lay,
His cursed hand gainst God, and on his altars daunst.
His trembling hand he would him force to put
And in his hand a Iacobs staffe, to stay
And his vnready weapons gan in hand to take.
His heauie hand he heaued vp on hye,
O hold thy mortall hand for Ladies sake,
Encountring fierce with single sword in hand,
In one alone left hand he now vnites,
And Pupill fit for such a Tutours hand.
And gaue it him in hand: his hand did quake,
And gaue it him in hand: his hand did quake,
He lifted vp his hand, that backe againe did start.
Out of his hand she snatcht the cursed knife,
And in her right hand bore a cup of gold,
And in her other hand she fast did hold
Amendment readie still at hand did wayt,
And taking by the hand that Faeries sonne,
The godly Matrone by the hand him beares
All in his hand, euen dead we honour should.
Whereof the keyes are to thy hand behight
Whose staggering steps thy steady hand doth lead,
With bloudy letters by the hand of God,
Who did her cause into thy hand commit,
Of Saxon kings, that haue with mightie hand
By this the dreadfull Beast drew nigh to hand,
So wondrous force, from hand of liuing wight;
And fiercely tooke his trenchand blade in hand,
With his almightie hand, and did it call
Behold I see the hauen nigh at hand,
But now they laurell braunches bore in hand;
Yet scratch my sonne, or rend his tender hand?
For he already plighted his right hand
And often semblaunce made to scape out of their hand.
And bound him hand and foote with yron chains.
Possessed of his Ladies hart and hand,
And knighthood tooke of good Sir Huons hand,
Whose hastie hand so farre from reason strayd,
Who made my hand the organ of his might;
Or cursed hand hath plaid this cruell part,
From thence it comes, that this babes bloudy hand
To weet, what dreadfull thing was there in hand;
Hold, ï¿½ deare Lord, hold your dead-doing hand,
As if their liues had in his hand beene gaged;
Thou little wotest, what this right hand can:
And in her hand a sharpe bore-speare she held,
O stay thy hand, for yonder is no game
Those deadly tooles, which in her hand she held,
He then with solemne oath and plighted hand
With wrathfull hand I slew her innocent;
And in his hand two darts exceeding flit,
Eftsoones his cruell hand Sir Guyon stayd,
As if it had by Natures cunning hand,
And euer held his hand vpon his hart:
What coward hand shall doe thee next to die,
Holding in hand a goodly arming sword,
Helpe with thy hand, or with thy counsell sage:
His hand, that trembled, as one terrifyde;
Then gan a cursed hand the quiet wombe
Ne toung did tell, ne hand these handled not,
The one in hand an yron whip did straine,
If euer couetous hand, or lustfull eye,
In his right hand an yron club he held,
Till Mammon did his hasty hand withhold,
And stretching forth his hand, did often thinke
But both the fruit from hand, and floud from mouth
For euill is at hand him to offend.
With trembling hand his troubled pulse gan try;
Sith wrathfull hand wrought not her owne desire?
With that, rude hand vpon his shield he laid,
That doth against the dead his hand vpreare,
With that his hand, more sad then lomp of lead,
And said; Faire Son, great God thy right hand blesse,
His hand relented, and the stroke forbore,
Thy cursed hand so cruelly haue swayd
But read what wicked hand hath robbed mee
With hard aduenture, which I haue in hand,
That in his hand a white rod menaged,
And in her hand a Poplar braunch did hold:
Which cunning Craftesman hand hath ouerlayd
There chaunced to the Princes hand to rize,
And with most cruell hand him murdred pittilesse.
But that they ouerran all parts with easie hand.
Then they which sought at first their helping hand,
As if the rest some wicked hand did rend,
